   Other labs: PT / PTT / INR:13.2/26.3/1.1, CK / CKMB /
   Troponin-T:166/7/0.17, Differential-Neuts:79.4 %, Lymph:14.6 %,
   Mono:3.4 %, Eos:2.2 %, Ca++:8.1 mg/dL, Mg++:2.0 mg/dL, PO4:3.3 mg/dL
   Assessment and Plan
   A+P: [**Age over 90 **]yo man with history of HTN and Afib not on anticoagulation who
   presented [**10-23**] s/p witnessed mechanical fall onto left hip.  Found to
   have left femoral neck fracture, admitted to medicine because of
   hypoxia.  In Afib with RVR starting in afternoon of [**10-24**] with
   worsening agitation and mental status changes, transferred to MICU for
   closer nursing support and rate control. This morning patient initially
   improved with rate control on diltiazem drip; however, became more
   agitated, heart rate increased.
   # Tachycardia/afib: possible etiologies include rebound tachycardia,
   but patient is receiving home doses of beta blockade as well as
   additional doses; other possible etiology is hypovolemia, possible
   given previous dose of Lasix, also patient oliguric with elevated
   creatinine, FENa <1%, slightly hypotensive which would be consistent
   with volume depletion, currently appears relatively euvolemic after 500
   mL fluid bolus (received 250mL, then half of second bolus of 500 mL
   after he removed his IV line). Tachycardia may be due to pain secondary
   to hip fracture, but patient is not reporting any pain; most likely due
   to agitation/delirium, as patient does appear delirious. Rate control
   attempted with diltiazem drip, rate did show some improvement with HR
   in 90s btwn [**4-3**] am, however patient became more agitated again and HR
   increased to 130s.
   -Haldol 2.5 mg IV as needed for agitation (reassess before each dosage)
   -Will avoid further fluids for now given possible pulmonary edema on
   CXR
   -Rate control with Diltiazem drip
   -Change home medication of Metoprolol to IV given that patient will
   most likely have difficulty with PO medications
   # Altered mental status: patient most likely has delirium secondary to
   multifactorial etiology: sundowning in hospital, pain secondary to hip
   fracture, hypoxemia, Afib. Urine C&S, blood cultures sent to rule out
   infectious causes of delirium. Patient received 2 doses of Haldol, one
   on admission to unit (2mg IV), 2.5 mg IV again as patient did not
   respond appropriately to initial Haldol dose, and another 2mg IV at
   6:30 am as patient continued to be agitated.  Given that patient does
   appear to have a component of sundowning as per report he was at
   baseline mental status prior to afternoon, may want to consider dose of
   oral Zyprexa this afternoon to prevent delirium in the evening if the
   patient clears during the day.
   -Haldol and 4 point restraints in acute setting (patient violent with
   staff on arrival), once acute period under better control will manage
   with delerium prevention
   -Call son first thing this morning to come in and see patient in an
   effort to redirect and improve delirium
   -Delirium prevention: frequent reorientation, removal of unnecessary
   procedures/medications, pain management, frequent family visits
   -Consider Zyprexa PO in afternoon (oral disintegrating tabs) to prevent
   sundowning
   # Hypoxemia: Concern for PE r/o with CT angio. Patient also thought to
   have pulmonary edema on initial CXR, given Lasix 10 mg IV x1 and
   oxygenation improved; however, Cr increasing, also oliguric (400 mL out
   yesterday) so may have a component of CHF. CT shows pulmonary edema and
   changes consistent with possible chronic aspiration as is demonstrated
   by tracheal secretions. Patient may be having fluid backup related to
   Afib given that he is thought to have pulmonary edema and also showing
   poor perfusion of his kidneys. Patient was covered for
   community-aquired PNA on the floor with Azithromycine and Ceftriaxone
   based on concern on CXR today for consolidation; however, he has had no
   fevers or leukocytosis.
   -ECHO to evaluate for CHF
   -check BNP with AM labs to compare to admission and further assess
   volume status
   -F/u fever curve, WBC count, if signs of infection will cover for
   aspiration pneumonia
   -consider changing diet to thickened liquids to prevent aspiration
   -F/u CXR this afternoon
   .
   #.ARF: Creatinine increased to 1.6 on [**10-24**] from 1 on admission; now
   improved after fluid challenge at 1.2.  Suggests prerenal etiology.
   Yesterday
s creatinine increase showed BUN/Cr> 20, which occurred in
   the setting of Lasix and IV contrast load with oliguria, ?urinary
   retention (bladder scan with 400mL residual).  Urine output [**10-24**]
   approximately 450 mL. Yesterday evening patient self-d/c
d Foley
   catheter, has been incontinent of a small amount of urine, do not have
   accurate I&Os. Possible etiologies include hypovolemia, CHF,
   contrast-induced nephropathy.
   -Patient recieved 500mL of fluid yesterday, creatinine improved with
   fluid challenge
   -Will wait for ECHO to assess cardiac status before more fluid given
   because of history of pulmonary edema
   -Patient also self d/c'd Foley catheter secondary to agitation. Low
   threshold for bladder scan if oliguric today, may need reinsertion of
   Foley catheter, also consider putting on condom catheter for now for
   more accurate measurement of I&Os
   .
   #.NSTEMI: Patient has had elevated troponins, [**10-24**] 3am 0.17, [**10-24**]
   5:15pm 0.25; [**10-25**] at 3:49 0.17, beginning to show downward trend. Most
   likely secondary to demand ischemia as EKG showing no focal specific
   changes.
   -Rate control with diltiazem (as above)
   .
   #.Left Hip Fracture: Patient seen by ortho in the ED, plan in place for
   hemiarthroplasty when medically stable. Discussed with ortho this
   morning, they are willing to take patient to OR as soon as this
   afternoon or tomorrow morning if patient is medically cleared.
   -No weight bearing left leg
   -Pain management with Tylenol
   -Calcium, vitamin D
   -Continue DVT prophylaxis with Heparin 5,000 u SQ TID
   .
   #Thrombocytopenia: Has had platelet count decreasing since arrival,
   admission ([**10-23**]) 182
 ([**10-24**]) 176
 ([**10-25**]) 133. Patient has not
   received enough fluids for this to be a dilutional effect. Only
   medication which may be responsible is Heparin.
   -Continue to monitor trend
   -If continues to decrease, will consider HIT and send HIT assay.
   FEN: Thickened liquids (NPO for now given that he may go for surgery
   later today).
   .
   PPX:
   -DVT ppx with Heparin 5,000 U SQ TID
   -Bowel regimen: Colace, Senna
   -Pain management with  Tylenol
   .
   ACCESS: PIV's
   .
   CODE STATUS: Full code, confirmed with son
   .
   EMERGENCY CONTACT: [**Name (NI) **] [**Name (NI) 4652**] [**Name (NI) 8953**] [**Telephone/Fax (1) 8954**]
   .
   DISPOSITION: ICU for now
   ICU Care

Based on the patient's daily progress note, here is a summary of the patient's condition and potential medical complications:

**Current Condition:**

The patient is an 90-year-old male with a history of hypertension and atrial fibrillation (AFib) who presented to the hospital after a witnessed mechanical fall onto his left hip. He has a left femoral neck fracture and was admitted to the medicine floor due to hypoxia. He was later transferred to the ICU for closer monitoring and rate control.

**Current Symptoms:**

* Tachycardia (heart rate 135 bpm) with increasing agitation and delirium
* Hypoxemia (SpO2 94%)
* Altered mental status with delirium
* Pain secondary to hip fracture
* Oliguric with elevated creatinine (1.2 mg/dL) and BUN/Cr > 20
* Possible pulmonary edema on CXR
* Thrombocytopenia with platelet count decreasing since admission

**Potential Medical Complications:**

1. **Tachycardia/Afib:** The patient's tachycardia may be due to rebound tachycardia, hypovolemia, pain secondary to hip fracture, or agitation/delirium. Rate control with diltiazem drip is ongoing.
2. **Altered Mental Status:** The patient's delirium may be secondary to multifactorial etiologies including sundowning, pain, hypoxemia, and AFib. Infectious causes of delirium are being ruled out with urine and blood cultures.
3. **Hypoxemia:** The patient's hypoxemia may be due to pulmonary edema, chronic aspiration, or community-acquired pneumonia. A CT angiogram is pending to rule out pulmonary embolism.
4. **Acute Kidney Injury (ARF):** The patient's creatinine has increased to 1.2 mg/dL, suggesting a prerenal etiology. Hypovolemia, CHF, and contrast-induced nephropathy are possible causes.
5. **Thrombocytopenia:** The patient's platelet count has decreased since admission, and he has not received enough fluids to cause a dilutional effect. Heparin may be responsible, and a HIT assay may be considered if the trend continues.
6. **Left Hip Fracture:** The patient has a left femoral neck fracture and is planned for hemiarthroplasty when medically stable.
7. **Pulmonary Edema:** The patient has pulmonary edema on CXR, which may be due to AFib, CHF, or chronic aspiration.

**Plan:**

* Continue rate control with diltiazem drip
* Monitor for signs of infection and cover for aspiration pneumonia if necessary
* Consider changing diet to thickened liquids to prevent aspiration
* F/u CXR and ECHO to assess cardiac status
* Monitor platelet count and consider HIT assay if trend continues
* Continue pain management with Tylenol and calcium, vitamin D
* Continue DVT prophylaxis with Heparin 5,000 U SQ TID
* Consider oral Zyprexa in the afternoon to prevent sundowning
* F/u fever curve, WBC count, and consider changing diet to thickened liquids

   improved with rate control on diltiazem drip; however, became more
   agitated, heart rate increased.
   # Tachycardia/afib: possible etiologies include rebound tachycardia,
   but patient is receiving home doses of beta blockade as well as
   additional doses; other possible etiology is hypovolemia, possible
   given previous dose of Lasix, also patient oliguric with elevated
   creatinine, FENa <1%, slightly hypotensive which would be consistent
   with volume depletion, currently appears relatively euvolemic after 500
   mL fluid bolus (received 250mL, then half of second bolus of 500 mL
   after he removed his IV line). Tachycardia may be due to pain secondary
   to hip fracture, but patient is not reporting any pain; most likely due
   to agitation/delirium, as patient does appear delirious. Rate control
   attempted with diltiazem drip, rate did show some improvement with HR
   in 90s btwn [**4-3**] am, however patient became more agitated again and HR
   increased to 130s.

   -Will avoid further fluids for now given possible pulmonary edema on

   most likely have difficulty with PO medications

   multifactorial etiology: sundowning in hospital, pain secondary to hip
   fracture, hypoxemia, Afib. Urine C&S, blood cultures sent to rule out
   infectious causes of delirium. Patient received 2 doses of Haldol, one
   on admission to unit (2mg IV), 2.5 mg IV again as patient did not
   respond appropriately to initial Haldol dose, and another 2mg IV at
   6:30 am as patient continued to be agitated.  Given that patient does
   appear to have a component of sundowning as per report he was at
   baseline mental status prior to afternoon, may want to consider dose of
   oral Zyprexa this afternoon to prevent delirium in the evening if the
   patient clears during the day.
   -Haldol and 4 point restraints in acute setting (patient violent with
   staff on arrival), once acute period under better control will manage
   with delerium prevention
   -Call son first thing this morning to come in and see patient in an
   effort to redirect and improve delirium
   -Delirium prevention: frequent reorientation, removal of unnecessary
   procedures/medications, pain management, frequent family visits
   -Consider Zyprexa PO in afternoon (oral disintegrating tabs) to prevent

Summary:

The patient is a 90-year-old male with a history of hypertension and atrial fibrillation (Afib) who presented to the hospital after a witnessed mechanical fall onto his left hip. He was admitted to the medicine department due to hypoxia and later transferred to the ICU for closer nursing support and rate control. The patient's current condition is characterized by tachycardia, atrial fibrillation, and agitation. He is receiving a diltiazem drip for rate control and has been administered Haldol for agitation.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Tachycardia/Afib: The patient's tachycardia and atrial fibrillation may be due to rebound tachycardia, hypovolemia, or pain secondary to his hip fracture. The patient's heart rate increased despite receiving a diltiazem drip, which may indicate that the drip is not effective in controlling his heart rate.
2. Altered Mental Status: The patient is experiencing delirium, which may be caused by sundowning, pain, hypoxemia, or Afib. He has received two doses of Haldol for agitation and is being considered for oral Zyprexa to prevent delirium in the evening.
3. Hypoxemia: The patient's oxygenation has improved since receiving Lasix, but his creatinine levels are increasing, suggesting that he may have chronic heart failure (CHF). He is also experiencing pulmonary edema, which may be related to Afib.
4. Acute Renal Failure (ARF): The patient's creatinine levels have increased from 1.0 to 1.6, and then decreased to 1.2 after a fluid challenge. This suggests a prerenal etiology, possibly due to hypovolemia, CHF, or contrast-induced nephropathy.
5. NSTEMI: The patient's troponin levels have been elevated, indicating possible myocardial injury. His EKG shows no focal specific changes, suggesting that the injury may be due to demand ischemia.
6. Left Hip Fracture: The patient has a left hip fracture and is at risk for complications such as deep vein thrombosis (DVT), pulmonary embolism (PE), and aspiration pneumonia.
7. Thrombocytopenia: The patient's platelet count has been decreasing since admission, which may be due to medication such as Heparin or an underlying condition.
8. Aspiration Pneumonia: The patient is at risk for aspiration pneumonia due to his altered mental status and inability to protect his airway.

Recommendations:

1. Continue rate control with diltiazem drip.
2. Monitor the patient's heart rate and rhythm closely.
3. Consider oral Zyprexa to prevent delirium in the evening.
4. Check the patient's BNP levels to assess volume status.
5. Monitor the patient's creatinine levels and urine output to assess for ARF.
6. Consider changing the patient's diet to thickened liquids to prevent aspiration.
7. Continue to monitor the patient's platelet count and consider HIT assay if it continues to decrease.
8. Continue DVT prophylaxis with Heparin.
9. Monitor the patient's oxygenation and consider ECHO to evaluate for CHF.
10. Consider changing the patient's pain management regimen to include stronger analgesics.

Based on the progress note, the patient is a 90+ year old male with a history of hypertension and atrial fibrillation (AFib) who presented with a witnessed mechanical fall onto his left hip, resulting in a left femoral neck fracture. He was admitted to the hospital due to hypoxia and was later transferred to the intensive care unit (ICU) for closer nursing support and rate control.

The patient's current condition is marked by tachycardia, with a heart rate in the 130s, and AFib. He is also experiencing agitation, confusion, and disorientation, which is likely related to delirium. His mental status is further complicated by sundowning, which is a common phenomenon in elderly patients.

The patient's laboratory results show elevated troponins, suggesting possible demand ischemia, and his creatinine level has increased, suggesting prerenal azotemia. His platelet count has also decreased, which may be related to heparin administration.

The patient's medical complications include:

1. Tachycardia/afib: The patient's tachycardia may be related to rebound tachycardia, hypovolemia, or pain secondary to his hip fracture. Rate control is being attempted with a diltiazem drip.
2. Altered mental status: The patient's delirium is likely multifactorial, with possible etiologies including sundowning, pain, hypoxemia, and AFib. Urine and blood cultures have been sent to rule out infectious causes.
3. Hypoxemia: The patient has a concern for pulmonary edema and chronic aspiration, which may be related to his AFib and poor perfusion of his kidneys. A computed tomography (CT) scan showed pulmonary edema and changes consistent with possible chronic aspiration.
4. Acute kidney injury (ARF): The patient's creatinine level has increased, suggesting prerenal azotemia. His urine output has been oliguric, and he has been incontinent of small amounts of urine.
5. Thrombocytopenia: The patient's platelet count has decreased, which may be related to heparin administration. Monitoring of the trend is recommended, and a HIT assay may be considered if the platelet count continues to decrease.
6. Left hip fracture: The patient has a left femoral neck fracture, which is being managed with pain medication and non-weight-bearing status.
7. NSTEMI: The patient's troponins have been elevated, suggesting possible demand ischemia.

The patient's plan includes:

1. Rate control with a diltiazem drip.
2. Management of delirium with frequent reorientation, removal of unnecessary procedures and medications, pain management, and frequent family visits.
3. Further evaluation of the patient's cardiac status with an echocardiogram.
4. Monitoring of the patient's platelet count and consideration of a HIT assay if the count continues to decrease.
5. Management of the patient's left hip fracture with pain medication and non-weight-bearing status.
6. Consideration of a change in diet to thickened liquids to prevent aspiration.
7. Further evaluation of the patient's pulmonary edema and chronic aspiration with a repeat CT scan.

Overall, the patient is at risk for several complications, including cardiac arrhythmias, respiratory failure, and sepsis. Close monitoring and management of his condition are necessary to prevent these complications and optimize his outcome.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 90-year-old man with a history of hypertension and atrial fibrillation, who presented to the hospital after a witnessed mechanical fall onto his left hip. He has a left femoral neck fracture, and was admitted to the ICU due to hypoxia and worsening agitation.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Vital signs: Tachycardia (135 bpm), hypertension (134/66 mmHg), and tachypnea (24 breaths per minute)
* Heart rhythm: Atrial fibrillation
* Respiratory support: Ventilator mask with oxygen saturation of 94%
* Neurological status: Delirious, with agitation and aggression
* Laboratory results: Elevated creatinine (1.2 mg/dL), elevated troponin (0.17 ng/mL), and abnormal ECG findings

The patient has several potential medical complications:

1. Tachycardia/afib: The patient's tachycardia may be due to rebound tachycardia, hypovolemia, pain secondary to hip fracture, or agitation/delirium. Rate control with diltiazem drip is being attempted.
2. Altered mental status: The patient has delirium, which may be secondary to sundowning, pain, hypoxemia, or atrial fibrillation. Urine and blood cultures have been sent to rule out infectious causes.
3. Hypoxemia: The patient has hypoxemia, which may be due to pulmonary edema, chronic aspiration, or community-acquired pneumonia. A CT angiogram has been ordered to rule out pulmonary embolism.
4. Acute kidney injury (ARF): The patient's creatinine has increased to 1.2 mg/dL, which may be due to prerenal etiology, contrast-induced nephropathy, or hypovolemia. Fluid challenge has improved his creatinine levels.
5. Non-ST elevation myocardial infarction (NSTEMI): The patient has elevated troponins, which may be secondary to demand ischemia. Rate control with diltiazem is being attempted.
6. Left hip fracture: The patient has a left hip fracture, which is being managed with pain management, calcium, and vitamin D.
7. Potential aspiration pneumonia: The patient has a history of chronic aspiration, and has been covered for community-acquired pneumonia.

The patient's plan of care includes:

* Rate control with diltiazem drip
* Delirium management with Haldol and 4-point restraints
* Pain management with Tylenol and calcium/vitamin D
* Fluid management with cautious fluid administration due to risk of pulmonary edema
* ECHO to evaluate for cardiac status and CHF
* Check BNP with AM labs to compare to admission and further assess volume status
* F/u fever curve, WBC count, and CXR to rule out infectious causes
* Consider changing diet to thickened liquids to prevent aspiration
* F/u creatinine levels to monitor for ARF
* Monitor for signs of NSTEMI and adjust treatment accordingly.

Based on the patient's progress note, the following potential medical complications have arisen or are of concern:

1. Tachycardia/Afib: The patient's atrial fibrillation has been persistent, and rate control has been attempted with diltiazem. The patient's tachycardia may be secondary to agitation, delirium, or hypovolemia.
2. Altered Mental Status: The patient has been experiencing delirium, which may be multifactorial in etiology, including sundowning, pain, hypoxemia, and Afib. The patient has received Haldol and will be monitored for further management.
3. Hypoxemia: The patient has been experiencing hypoxemia, which may be due to pulmonary edema, chronic aspiration, or CHF. A CT scan has shown pulmonary edema and changes consistent with chronic aspiration.
4. ARF (Acute Renal Failure): The patient's creatinine has increased, suggesting a prerenal etiology. The patient has received a fluid challenge, and the creatinine has improved. The patient's urine output has been oliguric, and the Foley catheter has been self-removed.
5. NSTEMI (Non-ST Elevation Myocardial Infarction): The patient has had elevated troponins, which may be secondary to demand ischemia. Rate control with diltiazem has been attempted.
6. Left Hip Fracture: The patient has undergone hemiarthroplasty, and pain management with Tylenol has been implemented.
7. Thrombocytopenia: The patient's platelet count has been decreasing, and the patient has not received enough fluids to cause a dilutional effect. Heparin may be responsible for this decrease.
8. Pulmonary Edema: The patient has been experiencing pulmonary edema, which may be due to CHF, hypovolemia, or fluid overload.
9. Infection: The patient has been covered for community-acquired pneumonia, and blood cultures have been sent to rule out infectious causes of delirium.

Based on the provided medical note, the patient is a 90-year-old man with a history of hypertension and atrial fibrillation who presented with a witnessed mechanical fall onto his left hip, resulting in a left femoral neck fracture. He was admitted to the ICU for closer nursing support and rate control due to worsening agitation and mental status changes.

The patient has undergone a hemiarthroplasty procedure and is currently intubated and sedated with propofol. He is receiving pain management with Tylenol and has been started on Diltiazem 30mg PO QID for rate control.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a heart rate of 77 bpm, blood pressure of 136/67 mmHg, and oxygen saturation of 100%. His respiratory support includes invasive ventilation with a CPAP/PSV mode, with a set tidal volume of 652 mL and a positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP) of 5 cmH2O.

The patient's laboratory results show elevated troponins, indicating possible myocardial infarction, and a B-type natriuretic peptide (BNP) level of 6,235, suggesting cardiac dysfunction. His complete blood count (CBC) shows a white blood cell count of 5.2 K/uL, hemoglobin of 10.7 g/dL, and platelet count of 133 K/uL.

The patient's medical complications include:

1. Tachycardia/afib: The patient's atrial fibrillation is likely secondary to agitation, and rate control has been achieved with a combination of diltiazem drip and calming agitation.
2. Altered mental status: The patient's mental status has been altered due to pain, change in environment, and sundowning, and he is currently sedated and intubated.
3. Hypoxemia: The patient is receiving invasive ventilation and is tolerating it well.
4. CHF: The patient's BNP level is elevated, suggesting cardiac dysfunction, and his CBC shows a white blood cell count of 5.2 K/uL, which may indicate an inflammatory response.
5. ARF: The patient's BUN and Cr levels are relatively stable, suggesting possible etiologies of hypovolemia, CHF, and contrast-induced nephropathy.
6. NSTEMI: The patient's troponins are elevated, indicating possible myocardial infarction, and his EKG shows no focal specific changes, suggesting demand ischemia.
7. Left hip fracture: The patient has undergone a hemiarthroplasty procedure and is currently intubated and sedated with propofol.
8. Thrombocytopenia: The patient's platelet count is decreased, possibly due to heparin therapy.
9. Anemia: The patient's hemoglobin level is decreased, possibly due to blood loss from surgery and dilutional effects from fluid administration.

The patient's plan of care includes:

1. Rate control with diltiazem drip and calming agitation.
2. Sedation and intubation for altered mental status.
3. Pain management with Tylenol.
4. DVT prophylaxis with Lovenox 30 mg SQ q12 hours.
5. Anemia management with iron supplements and blood transfusions as necessary.
6. Thrombocytopenia management with platelet transfusions as necessary.
7. Monitoring of the patient's vital signs, laboratory results, and medical complications.

The patient's disposition is currently ICU care, and his code status is full code.

Based on the patient's progress note, here is a summary of the patient's condition and potential medical complications:

**Summary:**

The patient is an elderly Caucasian male who presented with a witnessed mechanical fall onto his left hip, resulting in a left femoral neck fracture. He was admitted to the ICU due to hypoxia and was found to have atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response (RVR) and worsening agitation and mental status changes. He underwent hemiarthroplasty for his left hip fracture and is currently intubated and sedated with propofol.

**Potential Medical Complications:**

1. **Tachycardia/Afib:** The patient's atrial fibrillation with RVR is a concern, and rate control measures are in place to manage this condition.
2. **Altered Mental Status:** The patient's altered mental status is likely secondary to pain, change in environment, and sundowning. Delirium prevention measures are in place, including frequent reorientation, removal of unnecessary procedures/medications, pain management, and frequent family visits.
3. **Hypoxemia:** The patient's hypoxemia is a concern, and he is currently intubated and tolerating ventilation well. Extubation is planned once he is awake and ready.
4. **Acute Renal Failure (ARF):** The patient's BUN and Cr levels are stable, but there is concern for hypovolemia, CHF, and contrast-induced nephropathy. Fluid management is crucial to avoid pulmonary edema.
5. **Non-ST Elevation Myocardial Infarction (NSTEMI):** The patient's elevated troponins suggest possible myocardial infarction, and rate control measures are in place.
6. **Left Hip Fracture:** The patient's left hip fracture is a concern, and pain management is essential to avoid further complications.
7. **Thrombocytopenia:** The patient's platelet count is decreasing, and Heparin may be a contributing factor. Monitoring is crucial to determine the cause and prevent further decreases.
8. **Anemia:** The patient's HCT is decreasing, likely due to blood loss from surgery and dilutional effects from fluid administration. Transfusion may be necessary to maintain adequate HCT levels.

**Plan:**

1. Continue to monitor the patient's vital signs, cardiac rhythm, and laboratory results.
2. Maintain rate control measures for atrial fibrillation and NSTEMI.
3. Continue to manage pain with Tylenol and propofol.
4. Monitor for signs of infection and adjust antibiotic therapy as necessary.
5. Continue to monitor the patient's platelet count and consider HIT assay if the count continues to decrease.
6. Monitor the patient's HCT levels and transfuse as necessary to maintain adequate levels.
7. Continue to manage fluid administration carefully to avoid pulmonary edema.
8. Plan for extubation once the patient is awake and ready.

The patient is a 90-year-old male with a history of hypertension and atrial fibrillation, who presented with a left femoral neck fracture after a witnessed mechanical fall. He was admitted to the medicine service for hypoxia and later transferred to the MICU for closer nursing support and rate control due to worsening agitation and mental status changes. The patient underwent hemiarthroplasty and is currently intubated and sedated with propofol.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a heart rate of 77 bpm, blood pressure of 136/67 mmHg, and oxygen saturation of 100%. His respiratory support includes invasive ventilation with a tidal volume of 652 mL, positive end-expiratory pressure of 5 cmH2O, and fraction of inspired oxygen of 50%.

The patient's laboratory results show an elevated B-type natriuretic peptide (BNP) level, indicating possible cardiac dysfunction. His troponin levels are also elevated, suggesting possible myocardial infarction. His platelet count is decreased, and his hemoglobin level is decreasing, suggesting possible anemia.

Potential medical complications:

1. Cardiac complications:
	* CHF: Given the patient's elevated BNP level and decreased ejection fraction, there is a concern for cardiac failure.
	* NSTEMI: The patient's elevated troponin levels and decreased ejection fraction suggest possible myocardial infarction.
2. Respiratory complications:
	* Hypoxemia: The patient's oxygen saturation is 100%, but there is a concern for hypoxemia given his cardiac condition and respiratory support.
	* Ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP): The patient is intubated and receiving invasive ventilation, making him at risk for VAP.
3. Neurological complications:
	* Altered mental status: The patient's mental status is altered, and there is a concern for delirium.
	* Seizures: Given the patient's cardiac condition and respiratory support, there is a concern for seizures.
4. Hematological complications:
	* Thrombocytopenia: The patient's platelet count is decreased, and there is a concern for bleeding.
	* Anemia: The patient's hemoglobin level is decreasing, and there is a concern for anemia.
5. Infectious complications:
	* Pneumonia: The patient is at risk for pneumonia given his respiratory support and cardiac condition.
	* Sepsis: The patient's elevated white blood cell count and decreased platelet count suggest possible sepsis.
6. Surgical complications:
	* Wound infection: The patient's wound is at risk for infection given his cardiac condition and respiratory support.
	* Deep vein thrombosis (DVT): The patient is at risk for DVT given his cardiac condition and immobility.

Overall, the patient is at risk for various medical complications, and close monitoring and management are necessary to prevent and treat these complications.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 90-year-old male with a history of hypertension and atrial fibrillation, who presented with a witnessed mechanical fall onto his left hip, resulting in a left femoral neck fracture. He was admitted to the medicine service due to hypoxia and was later transferred to the MICU for closer nursing support and rate control.

The patient underwent hemiarthroplasty for his left hip fracture and was intubated and sedated with propofol due to agitation and mental status changes. He is currently on mechanical ventilation and has been experiencing tachycardia and atrial fibrillation.

The patient has been diagnosed with acute kidney injury (ARF) and is at risk for pulmonary edema due to his underlying heart failure and recent surgery. He also has thrombocytopenia, anemia, and elevated troponins, which may indicate demand ischemia.

The patient is at risk for several potential medical complications, including:

1. Pneumonia: Given his intubation and sedation, he is at risk for aspiration pneumonia.
2. Sepsis: His elevated troponins and BNP suggest potential cardiac or pulmonary sepsis.
3. Respiratory failure: His ARF and underlying heart failure may lead to respiratory failure.
4. Cardiac arrhythmias: His atrial fibrillation and tachycardia may worsen and lead to cardiac arrhythmias.
5. Bleeding: His thrombocytopenia and anemia may increase his risk of bleeding.
6. Infection: His recent surgery and prolonged hospitalization may increase his risk of infection.
7. Deep vein thrombosis (DVT): His prophylactic Lovenox therapy may not be sufficient to prevent DVT.
8. Pulmonary embolism (PE): His DVT prophylaxis may not be sufficient to prevent PE.
9. Gastrointestinal bleeding: His anemia and recent surgery may increase his risk of gastrointestinal bleeding.
10. Delirium: His prolonged sedation and intubation may lead to delirium.

The patient's treatment plan includes:

1. Rate control with diltiazem drip and metoprolol.
2. Pain management with Tylenol and calcium, vitamin D.
3. DVT prophylaxis with Lovenox.
4. Anemia management with transfusion as needed.
5. Thrombocytopenia management with platelet transfusion as needed.
6. ARF management with fluid restriction and close monitoring.
7. Respiratory support with mechanical ventilation.
8. Infection prophylaxis with stress ulcer prophylaxis and VAP prophylaxis.
9. Delirium prevention with frequent reorientation, removal of unnecessary procedures/medications, and pain management.

The patient's condition will require close monitoring and management to prevent potential complications and ensure optimal outcomes.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 90-year-old man with a history of hypertension and atrial fibrillation who presented with a witnessed mechanical fall onto his left hip, resulting in a left femoral neck fracture. He was admitted to the medicine service due to hypoxia and later transferred to the MICU for closer nursing support and rate control.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Vital signs: T 36.4C, HR 77 bpm, BP 136/67 mmHg, RR 15 breaths/min, SpO2 100%
* Hemodynamic monitoring: Invasive arterial line in place, CVP 10-20 mmHg
* Fluid balance: Total input 2,627 mL, total output 1,545 mL, with a positive balance of 1,082 mL
* Respiratory support: Intubated and mechanically ventilated, with a RSBI of 28 and a PEEP of 5 cmH2O
* Laboratory results: WBC 5.2 K/uL, Hct 35.4%, Plt 133 K/uL, Cr 1.2 mg/dL, BNP 6,235 pg/mL, Troponin-T 0.17 ng/mL

The patient's medical conditions and potential complications are as follows:

* Tachycardia/afib: likely due to agitation, with rate control achieved with a combination of diltiazem drip and calming agitation
* Altered mental status: likely secondary to pain, change in environment, and sundowning, with no infectious causes identified
* Hypoxemia: likely due to CHF, with an increased BNP level and no signs of pulmonary edema
* ARF: possible etiologies include hypovolemia, CHF, and contrast-induced nephropathy, with a stable BUN and Cr level
* NSTEMI: likely demand ischemia, with downward trending troponin levels and no focal specific changes on EKG
* Left hip fracture: s/p hemiarthroplasty, with no weight-bearing on the left leg and pain management with Tylenol
* Anemia: likely secondary to blood loss from surgery, with a decreasing Hct level and concern for possible hemolysis

The patient's plan of care includes:

* Rate control with diltiazem drip and calming agitation
* Sedation with propofol drip
* Pain management with Tylenol
* DVT prophylaxis with Lovenox 30 mg SQ q12 hours
* Anemia management with transfusion as needed for significant drop in HCT
* Hemolysis labs
* Thickened liquids for nutrition
* Bowel regimen with Colace and Senna
* Prophylaxis for DVT, stress ulcer, and VAP

The patient's disposition is to be continued in the ICU for further monitoring and management of his conditions.

Based on the provided progress note, I summarize the patient's health progress in the ICU as follows:

The patient is a 90-year-old male who presented with a witnessed mechanical fall onto his left hip, resulting in a left femoral neck fracture. He was admitted to the medicine service due to hypoxia and was later transferred to the MICU for closer nursing support and rate control. The patient underwent hemiarthroplasty and was extubated yesterday.

The patient's current condition is characterized by:

* Tachycardia/afib, likely due to agitation, which is managed with fluid bolus and increased dosage of diltiazem.
* Altered mental status, which is likely due to delirium, managed with frequent reorientation, removal of unnecessary procedures/medications, pain management, and frequent family visits.
* Hypoxemia, managed with nasal cannula oxygen therapy.
* ARF, possibly due to hypovolemia, CHF, or contrast-induced nephropathy, managed with fluid restriction and monitoring of renal function.
* NSTEMI, managed with rate control and downward trend in troponin levels.
* Left hip fracture, managed with orthopedic consultation and pain management with Tylenol.
* Anemia, managed with transfusion as needed for significant drop in HCT.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

* Pneumonia, given the patient's history of hypoxia and recent surgery.
* Sepsis, given the patient's history of fever and elevated white blood cell count.
* Pulmonary edema, given the patient's history of CHF and fluid overload.
* Deep vein thrombosis (DVT), given the patient's history of immobility and recent surgery.
* Aspiration pneumonia, given the patient's history of altered mental status and recent surgery.
* Hematoma around the hip, given the patient's history of bleeding during surgery.
* Further decline in renal function, given the patient's history of ARF and ongoing fluid restriction.

The patient's code status is full code, and his disposition is ICU care.

Based on the progress note, the patient is a 90-year-old male with a history of hypertension and atrial fibrillation (Afib) who presented with a witnessed mechanical fall onto his left hip, resulting in a left femoral neck fracture. He was admitted to the medicine service due to hypoxia and was later transferred to the intensive care unit (ICU) for closer nursing support and rate control.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Vital signs: Tachycardia with a heart rate of 67-138 bpm, blood pressure of 102/38-150/82 mmHg, respiratory rate of 16-34 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 97% on 3L nasal cannula.
* Hemodynamic monitoring: The patient's cardiac output is stable, with a central venous pressure of 12 mmHg and a pulmonary artery pressure of 25/15 mmHg.
* Fluid balance: The patient has received a total of 1,559 mL of fluid, with a positive fluid balance of 695 mL.
* Respiratory support: The patient is on standby ventilation with a tidal volume of 564 mL, peak inspiratory pressure of 6 cmH2O, and positive end-expiratory pressure of 0 cmH2O.
* Laboratory results: The patient's white blood cell count is 5.2 K/uL, hemoglobin is 9.5 g/dL, platelet count is 133 K/uL, and creatinine is 1.1 mg/dL. His troponin level is 0.17 ng/mL, and his B-type natriuretic peptide (BNP) level is 6,235 pg/mL.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

1. Tachycardia/afib: The patient's tachycardia may continue to worsen, leading to cardiac arrhythmias or even cardiac arrest.
2. Altered mental status: The patient's altered mental status may persist or worsen, leading to confusion, agitation, or even delirium.
3. Hypoxemia: The patient's hypoxemia may continue to worsen, leading to respiratory failure or even cardiac arrest.
4. Acute kidney injury (ARF): The patient's ARF may continue to worsen, leading to further fluid overload and electrolyte imbalances.
5. NSTEMI: The patient's NSTEMI may continue to worsen, leading to further cardiac damage and potential cardiac arrest.
6. Left hip fracture: The patient's left hip fracture may not heal properly, leading to further complications such as infection, nonunion, or avascular necrosis.

The patient's current plan of care includes:

* Rate control with metoprolol and diltiazem
* Agitation management with redirection and pain management
* Delirium prevention with frequent reorientation, removal of unnecessary procedures/medications, and pain management
* Hypoxemia management with oxygen therapy and respiratory support
* ARF management with fluid restriction and close monitoring
* NSTEMI management with rate control and close monitoring
* Left hip fracture management with pain management and close monitoring
* Anemia management with transfusion as needed

The patient's code status is full code, and his emergency contact is listed as [**Name (NI) **] [**Name (NI) 4652**] [**Name (NI) 8953**] [**Telephone/Fax (1) 8954**].

Based on the progress note, the patient is a 90-year-old male who was admitted to the ICU with a left femoral neck fracture and hypoxia. He was in atrial fibrillation (AF) and had a history of hypertension. He was extubated yesterday and is currently on nasal cannula oxygen at 3L with an oxygen saturation of 97%.

The patient has had several episodes of tachycardia, which is likely related to agitation. He has also had episodes of altered mental status, which has been managed with redirection and frequent reorientation. His urine culture was negative, and blood cultures are pending.

The patient's laboratory results show elevated troponins, which are consistent with non-ST elevation myocardial infarction (NSTEMI). His renal function appears to be stable, but he has had a significant drop in blood pressure when given fentanyl for pain control.

The patient's anemia is likely secondary to blood loss from surgery and a possible hematoma around the hip. He is being monitored closely, and transfusions will be given as needed.

The patient's condition is complex, and potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Pulmonary edema: Given the patient's history of atrial fibrillation and the possibility of hypoperfusion secondary to heart failure, there is a risk of pulmonary edema.
2. Aspiration pneumonia: The patient's altered mental status and risk of aspiration increase the risk of aspiration pneumonia.
3. Sepsis: The patient's elevated troponins and possible hematoma around the hip increase the risk of sepsis.
4. Acute kidney injury: The patient's anemia and possible hypoperfusion secondary to heart failure increase the risk of acute kidney injury.
5. Deep vein thrombosis: The patient's history of atrial fibrillation and immobilization increase the risk of deep vein thrombosis.

The patient's plan of care includes:

1. Rate control: The patient will continue to receive metoprolol and diltiazem to control his heart rate.
2. Delirium prevention: The patient will be monitored closely for signs of delirium, and frequent reorientation and redirection will be used to manage his altered mental status.
3. Pain management: The patient will continue to receive pain management with Tylenol, and calcium and vitamin D supplements will be given to prevent bone loss.
4. Anemia management: The patient's anemia will be monitored closely, and transfusions will be given as needed.
5. DVT prophylaxis: The patient will continue to receive DVT prophylaxis with Lovenox 30 mg SQ q12 hours.
6. Bowel regimen: The patient will receive a bowel regimen with Colace and Senna to prevent constipation.
7. ICU care: The patient will continue to receive ICU care, including monitoring of his vital signs, laboratory results, and medication management.

Based on the provided progress note, I summarize the patient's health progress in the ICU as follows:

The patient is a male with a chief complaint of hypotension. He was previously delirious but is now feeling much better and apologizing for his previous behavior. The patient was weaned off invasive ventilation on October 26th, 11:30 AM. His vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 36.2C (97.1F), heart rate of 67 beats per minute, and blood pressure of 102/38 mmHg.

The patient has atrial fibrillation (AFib) and is receiving pain control medication for acute and chronic pain. He has heart failure, systolic, acute, and is being managed with diltiazem and metoprolol. The patient's mental status is altered, but not due to delirium. He is at risk for respiratory failure, acute, but is not experiencing ARDS.

The patient's laboratory results show a white blood cell count of 5.2, hemoglobin of 26.9%, and platelet count of 133,000. His creatinine level is 1.1 mg/dL, and his troponin-T level is 0.17 ng/mL. His blood urea nitrogen (BUN) level is 22 mg/dL, and his creatinine clearance is 33 mg/dL.

The patient's plan includes continuing pain control, heart failure management, and monitoring his mental status. He will start a regular diet and begin weight-bearing activities. The patient will need reassessment of his medications over the next several days.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

1. Heart failure exacerbation: The patient's systolic heart failure may worsen if his medication regimen is not optimized or if he experiences increased fluid overload.
2. Respiratory failure: The patient's acute respiratory failure may progress to chronic respiratory failure if he does not recover from his underlying condition.
3. Infection: The patient's altered mental status and recent use of invasive ventilation make him at risk for developing a nosocomial infection.
4. Bleeding: The patient's platelet count is low, which may increase his risk for bleeding complications, especially if he is taking anticoagulant medications.
5. Kidney injury: The patient's creatinine level is elevated, which may indicate kidney injury or damage. Further monitoring and evaluation are necessary to determine the cause of his elevated creatinine level.
6. Hypoglycemia: The patient's blood glucose level is within a normal range, but he is receiving regular insulin sliding scale, which may increase his risk for hypoglycemia.
7. Electrolyte imbalances: The patient's electrolyte levels, such as potassium, magnesium, and phosphorus, may become imbalanced due to his underlying condition, medications, or fluid overload.
